_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Sysco Dallas, Inc.

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

1. Accidental Release prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

We at Sysco Dallas, Inc. are committed to protecting people and the environment.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as the design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration system at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate control measures to prevent possible releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Unforseeable, if such a release does occur, our highly trained employees are available to control and mitigate the release.  We are also completely coordinated with the Lewisville Fire Department, who provides our emergency response services.

2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled:

We have one chemical at our facility that is subject to the Process Safety and Risk Management regulations.  That substance is Ammonia (anhydrous) .  The maximum inventory of Ammonia (anhydrous) that is expected to be present at this facility, based upon process and operational requirements, is 26,000 pounds.

3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

Sysco Dallas, Inc. has taken the following steps, as required by 40 CFR Part 68 (EPA's Risk Management Planning regulations).  Our Ammonia (anhydrous) process is also subject to section 29 CFR 1910.119 (OSHA's Process Safety Management regulations).  Our facility is also subject to the EPA's Emergency Planning and Community Right To Know Act (EPCRA) Section 302 reporting requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place at our facility.

Process Safety Information:

Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our ammonia refrigeration process are identified and controlled efficie

ntly.  The methodology used to conduct these analyses is the What-If-Checklist.  These analyses were completed by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a frequency of at least every 5 years.  Any recommendations resulting from these analyses are scheduled and completed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures:

Sysco Dallas, Inc. maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to personnel who operate and/or maintain the process.

Training:

Sysco Dallas, Inc. has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that personnel who operate and/or maintain the ammonia refrigeration system are trained and certified.  New employees receive basic classroom training in process operations, followed by on-the-job supervision until they are evaluated and determined to be competent to work independently.  Refresher training is provided at least annually and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity:

Sysco Dallas, Inc. conducts documented maintenance inspections and tests on process equipment to ensure proper operation.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Qualified personnel complete inspections and tests only after they are trained and certified.  Any corrective actions noted during these inspections and tests are completed in a timely manner.

Management of Change:

Written procedures are in place at Sysco Dallas, Inc. to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and processes.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other persons whose job tasks are affected by a modi

fication of process operations, are promptly made aware of, and given, training regarding the modification.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews:

Pre-Startup Safety reviews related to new processes and modifications to established processes are conducted when they are required at Sysco Dallas, Inc.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for a safe start-up prior to placing any equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits:

Sysco Dallas, Inc. conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions of the Process Safety and Risk Management regulations are being implemented.  These audits are completed at least every three years and any noted corrective actions are assigned and scheduled in a timely manner.

Incident Investigation:

Sysco Dallas, Inc. promptly investigates any accident or incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of Ammonia (anhydrous).  These investigations are completed to identify the circumstances that caused the accident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the accident or incident from recurring.  All accident or incident investigation reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation:

Sysco Dallas, Inc. believes that process safety, risk management and accident prevention require a team effort.  Site personnel and contractors are urged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, site personnel have access to all information created as part of the implementation of the process safety and risk management regulations, including information resulting from the process hazard analyses in particular.

Contractors:

On occasion, Sysco Dallas, Inc. hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is comp

leted.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is conducted.  Contractors are informed of all known potential hazards related to their work on or near the ammonia refrigeration system.  Contractors are also informed of all of the procedures for notification, evacuation and accountability in the event of a site emergency due to an Ammonia (anhydrous) release.

4. 5-Year Accident History:

There have been no reportable accidents or incidents at this facility since it opened in 2002.

5. Emergency Response Plan:

Sysco Dallas, Inc. is included in the written community emergency response plan.  The facility also has it's own emergency response plan.  The emergency response plan includes specific actions to be taken in the event of an Ammonia (anhydrous) release.  The emergency response plan also includes procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies in the event of an Ammonia (anhydrous) release.  The emergency response plan also includes information on emergency health care.

The date of the most recent review or update of the emergency response plan was: December 15, 2010

The date of the most recent emergency response training for employees was: November 12, 2010

The local agency coordinating the facility emergency response plan is the Lewisville Fire Department.  Their phone number is: 
(972)-219-3580.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our Process Safety Management and Risk Management Planning programs.  We will continue our annual facility emergency notification, evacuation and accountability drills and planning and training site visits with the Lewisville Fire Department in the future.
